awd_titl_txt: CoPe EAGER: Collaborative Research: A GeoAI Data-Fusion Framework for Real-Time Assessment of Flood Damage and Transportation Resilience by Integrating Complex Sensor Datasets
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditional modeling approaches for flood damage assessment are often labor-intensive and time-consuming due to requirements for domain expertise, training data, and field surveys. Additionally, the lack of data and standard methodologies makes it more challenging to assess transportation network resilience in real-time during flood disasters. To address these challenges, this project aims to integrate novel data streams from both physical sensor networks (e.g., remotely-sensed data using unmanned aerial vehicles [UAVs]), and citizen sensor networks (e.g., crowdsourced traffic data, social media and community responsive teams connected through a developed mobile app). The goal is to develop a framework for real-time assessment of damage and the resilience of urban transportation infrastructures after coastal floods via the state-of-the-art computer vision, deep learning and data fusion technologies. The project will also advance Data Science through multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional collaborations. The project is expected to improve the sustainability, resilience, livability, and general well-being of coastal communities by having a direct impact on the effectiveness, capability, and potential of using both physical and social sensor data. This will in turn enable and transform damage assessments, and identify critical and vulnerable components in transportation networks in a more effective and efficient manner. The interdisciplinary research team, along with students and collaborators from different coastal regions, will facilitate the sharing of knowledge and technologies from different socio-environmental contexts and testing the transferability of the research outcomes.

The project will harmonize physical and citizen sensors within a geospatial artificial intelligence (GeoAI) data-fusion framework with a focus on three research thrusts: (1) unsupervised flood extent detection by integrating UAV images collected throughout this project with existing geospatial data (e.g., road networks and building footprints); (2) flood depth estimation using deep learning and computer vision techniques combined with crowdsourced photos and UAV imagery; and (3) assessment of the impact on and resilience of transportation networks based on near real-time flood and damage information. The innovative methodology will be demonstrated and deployed through collaborative efforts in response to future flood events as well as several historical storms. The project will produce open-source algorithms for future educational use, raw and processed datasets and associated processing software, a mobile app to engage community responsive science teams, and three research publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop a geospatial artificial intelligence (GeoAI) Data-fusion framework for real-time assessment of flood damage to civil infrastructure with better capabilities of modeling and assessing of the spatiotemporal vulnerability of urban transportation infrastructures after coastal floods. Given the importance of obtaining ground truth data with intensive manual annotation for training to build a classification model for extracting damaged features from both horizontal (e.g., flood extent) and vertical (e.g., water depth) perspectives, developing a rapid data collection method to assess transportation network resilience in real-time during disasters was regarded as the priority of the project.

The project established several inundation methods from PI-Fang's team utilizing both the latest Landsat-8 and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) collected data, as shown in Figure 1. It improved researchers' ability to exploit capacity and knowledge, bringing broader impacts within and beyond the immediate subject areas. The developed method was tailored for near real-time flood extent mapping, and the high expense of data annotation pointed to a need for "unsupervised" methods for feature extraction with as little human effort as possible based on traditional remote sensing imagery and pattern recognition. This project demonstrates a new way of near real-time flood mapping using UAVs coupled with high-resolution multispectral sensors in conjunction with new unsupervised extraction techniques that are robust and flexible enough for first responders to utilize or benefit from during real flooding events. The research team monitored dozens of locations using traditional and advanced weather products and mobilized to the various sites to collect aerial data and ground-truthing data for peak flow conditions of hurricane-induced flooding events during the project period.

The collected data have also been shared with PI-Huang's team for validating/improving a crowd-sourcing flooding reporting APP and serving as the input data for testing a flood depth estimation framework. The collected data include partially submerged structured ground objects, such as buildings, signposts, low-water-crossing gauges, and vehicles, that are normally hard to be captured with traditional approaches. PI-Fang also recruited undergraduate and graduate students to install and test the APP for reporting the damage and inundation at real locations. Mobile data included photos featuring impacts from the past hurricanes. This APP will continue to be promoted and utilized by PI-Fang's team and encouraged to be used by local communities. PI-Fang also experimented with crowd-sourced images during Hurricane Ian from social media platforms such as Instagram. By monitoring crowd-sourced photos of the hurricane's impact in near real-time, the project team was able to identify specific locations of flooding not reported by general media or predicted in inundation models.

PI-Fang's team has published nine peer-reviewed papers in high-impact journals, including the Journal of Hydrology, the Journal of Hydrologic Processes, Natural Hazards, Remote Sensing, and Science of the Total Environment. PI-Fang and others also presented the research results at many workshops and conferences on the topics of flood warning systems and resilient infrastructure, evaluating effects of vegetation types on rainfall-runoff response for flood control purposes, estimating radar rainfall data, and provided research updates in resilient transportation and stormwater infrastructure.

The synergetic research efforts make theoretical, interdisciplinary, technical, and practical contributions that altogether improve the sustainability, resilience, livability, and general wellbeing of communities in coastal cities. This project enhanced multi-university collaborations among the University of Texas at Arlington, University of Wisconsin at Madison, University of Hawaii, University of South Florida through collaborative efforts in flood-inundation-estimation methodology development and rapid response teams for disaster-related data collection. Not only did these efforts lead to direct collaboration within the universities but also with local fire departments, law enforcement, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Field Research Team, U.S. Geological Society staff and field members, city planners, and first responders during the 2020, 2021, and 2022 hurricane seasons. The project serves as a solid foundation for further enhancements for addressing the needs of rapidly deploying flooding assessment and multi-disciplinary data-driven research, and further enables the multi-institutional participations in activities involving data access, collaborative research, real-time analysis, and science education.

The existing rapid response team and system of deploying UAVs to capture perishable flood-related data were bolstered by training new students and improving the coordination of field activities. The research project has supported two undergraduate students, three Ph.D. students, and two postdoctoral researchers who fine-tuned the UAV-enabled collection system and data processing for flood classification and extent mapping. The topic of this research forms the basis of the dissertation for one of PI-Fang's Ph.D. students. Two undergraduate students have also been trained on UAV operations and data processing, including several underrepresented students. One postdoctoral researcher and one undergraduate student received their Part 107 FAA Certificate for Commercial Drone Operations as part of this project. The project helped two postdoctoral researchers grow into full-time academic career. The innovative project concept was demonstrated in three classes as an example to more than 300 students.


Last Modified: 04/26/2023
Modified by: Zheng N Fang
